title: Distributed charge - flux ratio at R to R-over-2

content.question: A solid, charged insulating sphere of radius <math alttext="uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> has a spherically symmetric charge distribution <math alttext="rho" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ρ</mi></math> that varies as a function of the distance <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> from the sphere’s center, where <math alttext="rho" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ρ</mi></math> and <math alttext="lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> are related by the equation <math alttext="rho of lowercase r, equals beta times lowercase r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>β</mi><mi>r</mi></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to lowercase r, less than or equal to uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>R</mi></math>. The electric flux through a spherical Gaussian surface of radius <math alttext="uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> concentric with the sphere is <math alttext="phi sub uppercase R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mi>R</mi></msub></math>, and the electric flux through a spherical Gaussian surface of radius <math alttext="uppercase R over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> concentric with the sphere is <math alttext="phi sub uppercase R over 2, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>. What is the ratio <math alttext="phi sub uppercase R, end sub, over Phi sub uppercase R over 2, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mi>R</mi></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mfrac></math>?
